docs.lead_paragraph: The snowy peaks of the south Tyrolean Alps feed the raging waters of the Passer River that runs through the town of Merano in northern Italy. For most of the 180 kilometer, or 112 mile, drive from Verona, the landscape is dotted with vineyards and spectacular medieval fortresses carved into the mountainside. Street signs along the way are in German and Italian, a reminder that until the end of World War I, the region was part of Austria.
docs.snippet: The snowy peaks of the south Tyrolean Alps feed the raging waters of the Passer River that runs through the town of Merano in northern Italy.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama returned from his trip to Asia facing some unsettling news: two new polls showed that his approval rating had dipped below 50 percent for the first time. To many of his critics, who had chafed as he enjoyed broad support among Americans even as many were critical of his handling of specific issues like the economy, this erosion is a tipping point, the end of Mr. Obama's perceived near-invulnerability.

headline.main: Reading the Tea Leaves in Obama's Sliding Numbers

docs.abstract: Gallop and Quinnipiac University polls showing Pres Obama's approval rating has dropped below 50 percent could mark end of Obama's perceived near-invulnerability; poll numbers worry Democratic strategists ahead of next year's tough Congressional elections; Republicans could find it easier to engage Obama as gap between how Obama is viewed and how his policies are viewed narrows; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The president’s approval ratings have fallen below 50 percent for the first time, raising issues for both parties a year before the midterm elections.

docs.lead_paragraph: Some lawmakers are staking their support for a health care overhaul on whether or not it creates a government-run health insurance plan -- the so-called public option -- to compete with private insurers. But a new poll by the Kaiser Family Foundation suggests that even though the public supports a public option, most people have other, higher priorities for the health legislation. Respondents to the poll were given a list of features of a hypothetical health care proposal and asked to name which were extremely or very important to them. Among Democratic respondents, 87 percent picked ''making sure affordable health insurance plans are available'' as their top priority.
docs.abstract: New Kaiser Family Foundation poll suggests public has higher priorities for health legislation than proposed government-run insurance that would compete with private insurers as so-called public option; some 87 percent of Democrats cite access to affordable coverage as their top priority; Republicans' top priority is not adding to budget deficit, while independents' top priority is access to affordable plans (M)
docs.snippet: Some lawmakers are staking their support for a health care overhaul on whether or not it creates a government-run health insurance plan -- the so-called public option -- to compete with private insurers. But a new poll by the Kaiser Family Foundation...

docs.lead_paragraph: When Senate Democratic leaders first went behind closed doors to complete the health care legislation, the only women in the room were either committee staff members or officials from the White House. The senators there -- Harry Reid of Nevada, Max Baucus of Montana and Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut -- reflected the Senate's predominant history as an old-boys' club. But to move the bill forward for full debate, the Democrats' last two crucial votes came from women: Senators Mary L. Landrieu of Louisiana and Blanche Lincoln of Arkansas.
docs.abstract: Bipartisan 'gang' of four women senators Mary L Landrieu, Blanche Lincoln, Susan Collins and Olympia J Snowe, could end up calling shots in health care debate; Democrats Landrieu and Lincoln provided last two votes needed to move legislation forward for full debate; Republicans Collins and Snowe may cast similarly crucial votes and are expected to be courted heavily by Democrats and White House; photo (M)
docs.snippet: When Senate Democratic leaders first went behind closed doors to complete the health care legislation, the only women in the room were either committee staff members or officials from the White House. The senators there -- Harry Reid of Nevada, Max...

docs.lead_paragraph: When Senate Democratic leaders first went behind closed doors to complete the health care legislation, the only women in the room were either committee staff members or officials from the White House. The senators there - Harry Reid of Nevada, Max Baucus of Montana and Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut - reflected the Senate's predominant history as an old-boys' club.

headline.main: Senate's Women Could Sway Health Bill

docs.abstract: As the Senate health care debate heads into the final stretch, there is the possibility of a bipartisan women's Gang of Four calling the shots.
docs.snippet: As the Senate health care debate heads into the final stretch, there is the possibility of a bipartisan women's Gang of Four calling the shots.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Prescriptions blog has noted on several occasions that the Great Health Care Debate of 2009, on many levels, is a numbers game. And that makes it all the more crucial to get the numbers right.

headline.main: More on That '98 Percent' Coverage Claim

docs.abstract: Setting the record straight on earlier reports that the Senate health legislation would result in 98 percent of the population's being covered. The number is 94 percent.
docs.snippet: Setting the record straight on earlier reports that the Senate health legislation would result in 98 percent of the population's being covered. The number is 94 percent.

docs.lead_paragraph: Several lawmakers are staking their support for a health care overhaul on whether or not it creates a government-run health insurance plan - the so-called public option - to compete with private insurers. But a new poll by the Kaiser Family Foundation suggests that even as the public supports a public option, they have other, higher priorities for the health legislation.

headline.main: Poll: Public Option Not Public's Priority

docs.abstract: The public option for insurance may matter more in Washington than with the actual public, a new report indicates.
docs.snippet: The public option for insurance may matter more in Washington than with the actual public, a new report indicates.

docs.lead_paragraph: At my son's very first check-up I had to fill out a form with his family history. As I scanned through the questions about cancer and heart disease and diabetes, and did a mental inventory of his relatives and their medical imperfections, I felt a rising sense of guilt -- these were the genes I had passed along to this perfect baby boy?
docs.abstract: Do you worry about the genes that have been passed to you from your parents and along to your children?
docs.snippet: Do you worry about the genes that have been passed to you from your parents and along to your children?

docs.lead_paragraph: On the House floor during a debate over the health care overhaul, he taunted a colleague who had been calling for his ouster. At a recent fund-raiser, he complained that the House speaker had made an end run around him and his committee. Confronted by a persistent conservative activist in a hallway, he let loose an expletive, telling the man to mind his own business.
docs.abstract: In other news: a case that could a blueprint for a big Manhattan terrorism trial, and details of a subway stabbing.
docs.snippet: In other news: a case that could a blueprint for a big Manhattan terrorism trial, and details of a subway stabbing.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama's scramble for a health care overhaul, like his dash across Asia last week, obscures an irony of his first year in office.

headline.main: Obama Seeks Time for Policies to Take

docs.abstract: Whether benefits from the president's policies will be realized in time for the elections in 11 months is a big question.
docs.snippet: Whether benefits from the president's policies will be realized in time for the elections in 11 months is a big question.
